channel.title: Can you uninstall linux if you dont like it?

item.title: Can you uninstall linux if you dont like it?
item.dc:creator: @Fasga Fasga
item.description:
@Fasga wrote:

Brazen Bull:

Try a “live CD” such as Knoppix. You can test linux without installing linux, or uninstalling windows.

If you do this, however, note that it will be noticeably slower this way than if you were to do a hard-drive install. So, don’t judge the operating system’s speed by the LiveCD’s speed.

Read full topic
item.source: Can you uninstall linux if you dont like it?

item.title: Can you uninstall linux if you dont like it?
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

When you Install Linux, you wipe your Hard Drive, unless you use it’s partition program. So if you were to Format your hard drive, it would remove Linux, and all the other files on the HD. Now you could install Windows 95/98/98SE/ME/2000/XP/Vista and you’d have an OS on your HD. If you’re worried about converting to Linux from Windows, you should try using the Live CD, it allows you to boot from it and run Ubuntu/Kubuntu off of it.

Read full topic
item.source: Can you uninstall linux if you dont like it?

item.title: Can you uninstall linux if you dont like it?
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

You don’t ‘uninstall’ an OS…

If you mean delete it, sure, but then unless you had it in a dual boot you’d just POST and then it sits there because there’s nothing to boot from.

Follow Ron’s dual boot tutorial if you’re concerned that you may not like it.

Read full topic
